columns.text: In this exercise, we will discuss the effect of an increase in rate on the present and future value.

**Increasing the rate will decline the present value of an annuity amount**

First, let's understand that the discount rate is an integral component in calculating the present value. In calculating the present value, the discount rate is used as the denominator to divide the net cashflows.

**Increasing the rate will result in a higher future value of an annuity amount**

The interest rate is used to multiply the cash flows in the future value of an annuity computation. Hence a higher rate will result in a higher value future value.

To conclude, the relationship of the present value and future value to the rate is diverse. A rate increase will result in a lower present value computation, whereas it will increase the amount value in future value computation.
This task requires us to determine the change in present/future value of annuity, knowing there is an increase in interest rate $r$.

To be able to discuss this, let's remind ourselves of the way present and future values of annuity are calculated.

**Present value of annuity** is calculated as:

$$\text{PV}=\text{C} \times \frac{1-\left(\dfrac{1}{1+\text{r}}\right)^\text{t}}{\text{r}}$$



where:

 $\text{C}$ = deposit value, constant per definition of annuity;\
 $\text{r}$ =  interest rate (in decimals);\
$\text{t}$ = time passed.

**Future value of annuity** is calculated as:

$$\text{FV}=\text{C} \times \frac{\left(1+\text{r}\right)^t-1}{\text{r}}$$

Parameters are the same ones used in present value. Also, for the ease of discussion, we will consider $\text{t}$ to be constant in both cases.

## Requirement 1

Let's begin with observing how the interest rate affects annuity future value.

We can see that numerator, also known as **annuity future value factor** $(1+\text{r})^\text{t}-1$ increases, but so  does the denominator, therefore, we need to compare the increase of both terms to see how the total value changes.

The term $(1+\text{r})^\text{t}-1$ grows faster than $\text{r}$; or more technically, 
$((1+\text{r})^\text{t}-1)$ > $\dfrac{1}{\text{r}}$, therefore the **future value will increase** .

As this is somewhat unintuitive to determine at face value, we will insert actual numbers to determine the veracity of the conclusion.

We will use following values:

| Particulars| Amounts|
|--|--|
|Interest rate 1| 100% = 1| 
|Interest rate 2| 200% = 2| 
|Period| 2 years| 

Note: These rates are chosen for ease of demonstration and calculation, as the give nice and clear integers instead of more cumbersome decimals, interest rates are normally never this high.

In case of $\text{r}_2$, we will have:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{FV}_2&=\text{C} \times \frac{\left(1+2\right)^2-1}{1}\\
&=\text{C} \times \frac{9-1}{2}\\
&=4\times \text{C}
\end{aligned}$$

which proves the correctness of the above inference.

## Requirement 2

Now let's see how interest rate affects annuity present value.

Let's look at **annuity present value factor** $1-\dfrac{1}{(1+r)^t}$. 

As $\text{r}$ increases, the term $\dfrac{1}{(1+\text{r})^\text{t}}$ will decrease, however, $1-$decreasing value = increasing value (for example $1-0.3>1-0.5$)

Contrary to the future value, now we have the case where $\dfrac{1}{\text{r}}>1-\dfrac{1}{(1+\text{r})^\text{t}}$, which means that **present value decreases**.

Let's again insert the numbers to confirm the veracity of the statement.

We will again use the same values used for future value:

| Particulars| Amounts|
|--|--|
|Interest rate 1| 100% = 1| 
|Interest rate 2| 200% = 2| 
|Period| 2 years|

In case of $\text{r}_2$, we will have:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{PV}_2&=\text{C} \times \frac{1-\left(\dfrac{1}{1+2}\right)^2}{2}\\[15pt]
&=\text{C} \times \frac{1-0.11}{2}\\[15pt]
&=0.445 \times \text{C}
\end{aligned}$$

which proves the correctness of the above inference.
